div.l: Thogh þat he shuld holy chirch deuoure
Grete sokne hath þis Milleward out of doute
With whete and Malt of al þe londe aboute
And namelich þer was a grete college
Men cleped þe soler halle of Cantebrigge
Ther was hir whete and eke hir Malt y grounde
And on a day it happed in a stounde
Syke lay þe manciple on a maladye
Men wenden wisly þat he shulde dye
For which þis Miller stale boþ mele and corne
An hondred tyme more þan by forn̄
For ther byforn he stale but curteislye
But now he was a thef outerageously
For which þe wardeyne childe made a fare
But þerof sette þe Miller noght a tare
He craked bost and swore it was not so
Then were there yonge pouer scolers two
Þat dwelten in þe halle of which y seye
Testyf þey were and lusty to pleye
And oonly for hir mirth and reverie
Vpon þe wardeyn besyly þey crye
To yeve hem leve but a litel stounde
To go to Mille and sen her corn ygrounde
And hardelych þei durst ley her nekke
Þe Milleward shuld not stelen hem half a pekke
Of corn̄ by sleyghte ne by force hem reve
And atte last þe warden yaf hem leve
Iohn hight þat on and aleyn hight þat oþer
Of oon town̄ were þey born̄ þat hight strother
Fer in þe north y kan not telle whare
Þis aleyn̄ makeþ redy al his gere
And on an horce þe sak he cast anoon̄
Forþ goth aleyn þe clerk and also Iohn
With gode swerde and bokeler by hir syde
Iohn knew þe wey hem neded no gyde
And at þe last þe sak a doun he layth
Aleyn spake first al haile Symkyn in feyth
How fares þe feire doghter and þi wyfe
Aleyn̄ welcome qduod symkyn by my lyfe
And Iohn also how now what do ye here
